passage_list.text: Last May, 19 children and two of their teachers were murdered at Robb Elementary School in Uvalde, Texas. The next day, Quinta Brunson, the creator and star of the ABC sitcom Abbott Elementary, shared a message—one of many— that she’d received in response to the massacre: a request from a fan that she write a school-shooting story line into her comedy. 'People are that deeply removed from demanding more from the politicians they’ve elected and are instead demanding ‘entertainment,’' Brunson wrote on Twitter. 'I can’t ask ‘are yall ok’ anymore because the answer is ‘no.’'

Brunson’s frustration was understandable. Yet it’s also hard to blame the fans who, as they grieved a real shooting, sought comfort in a fictional one. They have been conditioned to expect that the news will instantaneously become entertainment.

Almost as soon as a big event happens, a production company repurposes it as a pseudo-fiction. In 2019, two Boeing 737 Max airplanes crashed, killing 346 people; by early 2020, Variety was announcing, 'Boeing 737 Max Disaster Series in Works.' In July 2020, The Hollywood Reporter shared that Adam McKay’s next project at HBO would 'take on the timeliest of subjects: the race to develop a vaccine for COVID-19.' In January 2021, Reddit users collaborated to inflate the stock of the video-game store GameStop; a week later, MGM announced that it had landed the film rights to a book proposal—a book proposal, not an actual book—about the story. In the metaverse, history repeats itself, first as tragedy, then as wry dramedy on HBO Max.

Producers have been ripping plots from the headlines for as long as there have been headlines to rip them from. The difference today is the speed and the scale of the conversion. There are commercial reasons for this frenzy of optioning. In general, plundering reality is much easier and cheaper than inventing something new. The streaming platforms wouldn’t keep making the series, however, if viewers didn’t watch them. And watching them can be disorienting.

The tagline at the start of every episode of Inventing Anna, the 2022 Netflix series, neatly sums up the approach of the new 'ripped from the headlines' genre: 'This whole story is completely true. Except for all of the parts that are totally made up.' Inventing Anna is the lavishly fictionalized story of Anna Sorokin (more commonly known by her alias, Anna Delvey), a Russian woman who pretended to be a German heiress to gain the trust and then the money of rich people in New York City. It is a tale about lies so brazen that they revealed some well-disguised truths—about the magical thinking of high finance, about America’s enduring susceptibility to the con artist.

Inventing Anna is based on a 2018 New York magazine story by the journalist Jessica Pressler. The show weaves the article—lyrically rendered but truthfully told—into its own version of the story. Inventing Anna is by turns flashy, cheeky, and insightful. It operates in the realm that the postmodernists call hyperreality: Its colors are saturated; its pace is frenetic; it plays, sometimes, less as a drama than as a music video. Most of all, the show sells the idea that an unstable relationship between fact and fiction is its own kind of fun. In that, Inventing Anna is typical. WeCrashed, Super Pumped: The Battle for Uber, The Dropout, and many other series repurpose high-profile news events as glossy amusements. Gaslit, Winning Time, A Friend of the Family, Pam & Tommy, and American Crime Story do similar work with history so recent, it can barely be considered history at all. Many of them are self-consciously products of 'prestige TV,' and many of them are quite good: smartly written, slickly produced, and performed by talented actors.

The shows also deliver a voyeuristic thrill that can be difficult for even the most thoroughly reported and artfully told journalism to rival. The promise of the metaverse has always been the ability to inhabit realms that would otherwise be closed to us: In a recent ad, Meta’s Quest 2 headset transports one young woman into an NFL scrum and another into the Ironman suit. A series like The Crown provides a similar experience. We sit with the Royal Family in their bedrooms. We see them fighting. We see them weeping. This is a biopic about lives still being lived.

Of course, such voyeurism is possible only because the shows are not bound by the rules of nonfiction. Like so many entries in the genre, The Crown combines finicky photorealism and breezy artistic license. The series offers a stitch-by-stitch re-creation of the 'revenge dress' that Princess Diana debuted after Prince Charles’s infidelity came to light; it also fabricates dialogue, events, and entire characters. In 2020, the United Kingdom’s culture secretary asked Netflix to add a disclaimer to the show making clear that it is, fundamentally, a work of fiction. Netflix declined, saying it was confident that viewers knew the show was fiction. Yet its executives surely understand that the series is appealing precisely because it presents its fictions with the swagger of settled fact.

One night this past fall, my partner and I were watching an episode of Gaslit (about the life of the Watergate celebrity Martha Mitchell). We were both side-screening with our phones, and at some point we realized we were doing the exact same thing: combing Wikipedia to find out whether the scene we’d just watched had actually happened. In this, we were missing the point. When you’re watching a show like Gaslit or The Crown, you are supposed to accept that the story is true in a broad sense, not a specific one. You are not meant to question the difference between nonfiction and a story that’s been 'lightly' fictionalized. And you are definitely not supposed to be on Wikipedia, trying to cross-reference the real history against the one you’re seeing on Starz.

questions.question: What is the main idea of the first passage?

options.A: The impact of school shootings on society
options.B: Quinta Brunson's response to a fan's request
options.C: The role of politicians in preventing tragedies
options.D: The importance of entertainment in difficult times

questions.explanation: The passage focuses on Quinta Brunson's reaction to a fan's request to include a school-shooting storyline in her comedy, making B the correct answer.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Focus on the central subject and the author's main point in the passage.

questions.question: As used in the passage, the word 'conditioned' most nearly means:
questions.explanation: The word 'conditioned' in this context refers to the fans being trained or accustomed to expecting news to become entertainment.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use context clues to determine the meaning of unfamiliar words.

questions.question: Based on the passage, what can be inferred about the relationship between real-life events and entertainment?

options.A: Entertainment often distorts real-life events beyond recognition
options.B: Real-life events are quickly adapted into entertainment with little regard for accuracy
options.C: Entertainment based on real-life events is always critically acclaimed
options.D: Real-life events are rarely used as inspiration for entertainment

questions.explanation: The passage describes how real-life events are rapidly turned into entertainment, often with fictionalized elements, suggesting a lack of emphasis on accuracy.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Look for implied meanings and draw logical conclusions based on the text.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the fourth passage?

options.A: To criticize the commercialization of real-life events
options.B: To explain why producers adapt real-life events into entertainment
options.C: To highlight the negative effects of streaming platforms
options.D: To argue that fictionalized stories are more engaging than real-life events

questions.explanation: The passage explains the commercial reasons behind the rapid adaptation of real-life events into entertainment, making B the correct answer.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Identify the author's purpose by analyzing the main ideas and supporting details.

questions.question: Which choice best supports the idea that 'Inventing Anna' blurs the line between fact and fiction?

options.A: The show is based on a 2018 New York magazine story
options.C: The show reveals truths about high finance
options.D: The show is performed by talented actors

questions.explanation: The passage states that 'Inventing Anna' is 'lavishly fictionalized,' which directly supports the idea that it blurs the line between fact and fiction.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use direct evidence from the text to support your answer.

questions.question: How does the description of 'Inventing Anna' in the passage relate to the broader trend of 'ripped from the headlines' shows?

options.A: It is an exception to the trend due to its focus on fiction
options.B: It exemplifies the trend by repurposing a high-profile news event
options.C: It criticizes the trend by highlighting the dangers of fictionalization
options.D: It diverges from the trend by focusing on historical events

questions.explanation: The passage describes 'Inventing Anna' as part of the trend of repurposing high-profile news events into entertainment, making B the correct answer.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Compare and contrast ideas across different parts of the text to understand broader trends.

questions.question: Which choice best describes the rhetorical effect of the comparison between the metaverse and 'The Crown'?

options.A: It emphasizes the immersive nature of both experiences
options.B: It highlights the technological limitations of the metaverse
options.C: It critiques the voyeuristic aspects of 'The Crown'
options.D: It suggests that the metaverse is more entertaining than traditional media

questions.explanation: The comparison emphasizes how both the metaverse and 'The Crown' create immersive experiences that allow viewers to inhabit otherwise inaccessible worlds.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Analyze how comparisons and analogies contribute to the author's argument.

questions.question: As used in the passage, the word 'swagger' most nearly means:
questions.explanation: In this context, 'swagger' refers to the confident presentation of fictional elements as if they were factual.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use context clues to determine the meaning of nuanced words.

questions.question: What can be inferred about the author's view of shows like 'Gaslit' and 'The Crown'?

options.A: They are best enjoyed without questioning their accuracy
options.B: They are more educational than entertaining
options.C: They should always include disclaimers about their fictional nature
options.D: They are less engaging than traditional documentaries

questions.explanation: The author suggests that viewers are 'missing the point' when they try to verify the accuracy of these shows, implying that they are meant to be enjoyed without such scrutiny.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Infer the author's perspective by analyzing their tone and implications.

questions.question: Which choice best completes the sentence: 'When you’re watching a show like Gaslit or The Crown, you are supposed to accept that the story is true in a broad sense, not a specific one. You are not meant to question the difference between nonfiction and a story that’s been 'lightly' fictionalized.'

questions.score_improvement_tip: Pay attention to sentence structure and logical connectors to ensure coherence.

scoring_guidelines.700_level_performance: Students scoring at this level show strong comprehension and reasoning skills but may struggle with higher-level analysis and synthesis.

explanation_summary.hard_questions: Hard questions test advanced analytical and reasoning skills, often requiring students to infer meaning or analyze complex text structures.
explanation_summary.medium_questions: Medium questions assess comprehension and vocabulary in context, with a focus on understanding main ideas and details.
